advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> ...You will get more performances than with the IBM PC, the Apple II, TRS80 Model II or TRS80 Model III along with software support of TRSDOS or CP/M, the two most widely used operating systems. This means you, the user, can select from the largest base of business or personal software... <font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US DEALER ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Until now, parents interested in expanding their children's educational experience, turned to expensive encyclopedias. With the advent of the PET personal computer a new avenue of visual learning is now available for your youngsters for as low as $595....<br><br> ... Your youngster will think he's playing, you'll know he's learning with the remarkable PET... </font><br><br> At the time, parents often thought a personal computer could help their youngsters learning, but 80% of the home computers sold in the 80's was used only for playing. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Douglas Reedy</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8086 VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In september 1982, Seattle Computer provided the 8086 version of the Gazelle with a free set of software: Microsoft MS-DOS, GW-Basic and the Perfect Writer word processor. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #4 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A step toward the future" <br><br> Hmmmm.....</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #6</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, July 1982 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> We know your question: How could Olivetti have developped a better personal computer than the other giants?<br> The answer is in a word: Experience. Olivetti introduced the world's first desktop computer in 1965. Since then, we've continued to market a variety of minicomputers and microcomputers to a wide range of users...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (NOV. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br> The Acorn Atom is a definitive personal computer. Simple to build, simple to operate. A powerful, full facility computer with all the features you would expect.<br> Just connect the assembled computer to any domestic TV and power source and you are ready to begin. (Power requirement: 8V at 800mA). There is an ATOM power unit available. <br><br> Free with every ATOM, kit or built, is a computer manual. The first section explains and teaches you BASIC, the language that most personal computers and the ATOM operate in. The instructions are simple and learning quickly becomes a pleasure. You'll soon be writing your own programs. The second section is a reference manual giving a full description of the ATOM's facilities and how to use them. Both sections arE fully illustrated with example programs. <br><br> <b>The standard ATOM includes:</b><br> HARDWARE<br> . Full-sized QWERTY keyboard. 6502 Microprocessor. Rugged injection-moulded case. 2K RAM. 8K HYPER-ROM<br> . 23 integrated circuits and sockets. Audio cassette interface. UHF TV output. Full assembly instructions<br> SOFTWARE<br> . 32-bit arithmetic (:i: 2,000,000,000). High speed execution. 43 standard/extended BASIC commands. Variable length strings (up to 256 characters) . String manipulation functions. 27 x 32 bit integer variables<br> . 27 additional arrays. Random number function. PUT and GET byte. WAIT command for timing. DO-UNTIL construction . Logical operators (AND, OR, EX-OR) . Link t machine - code routines. PLOT commands, DRAW and MOVE <br><br> <b>The ATOM modular concept</b><br> The ATOM has been designed to grow with you. As you build confidence and knowledge you can add more components. For instance the next stage might be to increase the ROM and RAM on the basic ATOM from 8K + 2K to 12K + 12K respectively. This will give you a direct printer drive, floating point mathematics, scientific and trigonometric functions, high resolution graphics.<br> From there you can expand indefinitely. Acorn have produced an enormous range of compatible PCB's which can be added to your original computer. For instance: A module to give red, green and blue colour signals Teletext VDU card (for Prestel and Ceefax information) An in-board connector for a communications loop interface - any number of ATOMs may be linked to each other or to a master system with mass storage/hard copy facility. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Paul Durrant</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (FEB. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Educatel advert for their correspondance courses using the Microlab system.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Doctors, it gonna cure your work" <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said:<br><br> No waiting for software<font color="#666666"> ...This exciting micro has fired the imagination of programmers who are busy developping new software to take full advantage of its performance capabilities...</font><br><br> No wait state<font color="#666666"> ...One advantage is the total elimination of memory access wait states so that interaction between the processor, RAM and disk drive is speeded up...</font><br><br> A free p-System for those who don't wait <font color="#666666"> ...A free p-System operating system and PASCAL, FORTRAN 77 and BASIC compilers which alone lists for $1475, we're now including free with the Sage II...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Compatible with you know who.<br> Equiped like nobody.<br> Priced like Amstrad".<br> <br> Single drive, monochrome monitor = 4997 FF + VAT<br> Double drive, monochrome monitor = 6290 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, colour monitor = 6890 FF + VAT<br> Double drive, colour monitor = 8190 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, 20 MB hard-disk, monochrome monitor = 9990 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, 20 MB hard-disk, colour monitor = 11890 FF + VAT</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>UK advert from Personal Computer World magazine, October 1983</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
The IVEL Ultra is a Croatian computer made by Ivasim Electronika. Its creator was Branimir Makanec. They were made in a little city near Zagreb called Ivanic Grad. The main characteristic of the Ivel Ultra is to be compatible with the Apple II.
It is equiped with one or two 5.25" floppy disk drives. Its Basic is compatible with the Apple one, and its operating system called IDOS is compatible with Apple DOS 3.3
On top of that, the Ivel Ultra has a second processor, a Zilog Z80, mainly used to offer CP/M compatibility.
The were different versions of this computer. The brown version is the oldest model (made in 1984-1986) and the white version is newer (made in 1987-1990).
___________
Contributor: Sveto (pictures & info)
computer.name: Ivel Ultra
